description: Port jest-extended matchers to roblox-ts. Each story adds matcher impl + spec files following patterns in porting-rules.md and existing toBeTrue reference.

userStories.title: Port pass and fail matchers
userStories.description: As a developer, I want pass() and fail() matchers so I can explicitly pass or fail tests with custom messages.
acceptanceCriteria: Create src/matchers/pass.ts and src/matchers/fail.ts following toBeTrue pattern
Add pass and fail to CustomMatchers in types.d.ts: pass(message?: string): R; fail(message?: string): R
userStories.notes: Implement each matcher one at a time. Per matcher: impl + spec + types + exports → typecheck → lint → test → commit. Use semantic commits with matcher name as scope, e.g. feat(pass): add pass matcher. Then start next matcher.

userStories.title: Port toBeFalse and toBeBoolean
userStories.description: As a developer, I want toBeFalse and toBeBoolean matchers for boolean assertions.
acceptanceCriteria: Add toBeFalse and toBeBoolean to CustomMatchers in types.d.ts
userStories.notes: Implement each matcher one at a time. Per matcher: impl + spec + types + exports → typecheck → lint → test → commit. Use semantic commits with matcher name as scope, e.g. feat(pass): add pass matcher. Then start next matcher.

userStories.title: Port toBeNumber, toBeString, toBeFunction
userStories.description: As a developer, I want type-checking matchers for numbers, strings, and functions.
acceptanceCriteria: Create impl + spec for each: to-be-number, to-be-string, to-be-function
Add all three to CustomMatchers in types.d.ts
userStories.notes: Implement each matcher one at a time. Per matcher: impl + spec + types + exports → typecheck → lint → test → commit. Use semantic commits with matcher name as scope, e.g. feat(pass): add pass matcher. Then start next matcher.

userStories.title: Port toBeObject and toBeArray
userStories.description: As a developer, I want type-checking matchers for objects and arrays.
acceptanceCriteria: Create impl + spec for each: to-be-object, to-be-array
toBeArray: use typeIs(actual, 'table') and check for array-like structure
userStories.notes: Implement each matcher one at a time. Per matcher: impl + spec + types + exports → typecheck → lint → test → commit. Use semantic commits with matcher name as scope, e.g. feat(pass): add pass matcher. Then start next matcher.

userStories.title: Port toBeEven and toBeOdd
userStories.description: As a developer, I want matchers to check if numbers are even or odd.
acceptanceCriteria: Create impl + spec for each: to-be-even, to-be-odd
userStories.notes: Implement each matcher one at a time. Per matcher: impl + spec + types + exports → typecheck → lint → test → commit. Use semantic commits with matcher name as scope, e.g. feat(pass): add pass matcher. Then start next matcher.

userStories.title: Port toBePositive and toBeNegative
userStories.description: As a developer, I want matchers to check number sign.
acceptanceCriteria: Create impl + spec for each: to-be-positive, to-be-negative
userStories.notes: Implement each matcher one at a time. Per matcher: impl + spec + types + exports → typecheck → lint → test → commit. Use semantic commits with matcher name as scope, e.g. feat(pass): add pass matcher. Then start next matcher.

userStories.title: Port toBeInteger and toBeFinite
userStories.description: As a developer, I want matchers for integer and finite number checks. These need Luau-specific implementations.
acceptanceCriteria: Create impl + spec for each: to-be-integer, to-be-finite
toBeInteger: use typeIs(x, 'number') && x === x && x % 1 === 0 (no Number.isInteger)
toBeFinite: use typeIs(x, 'number') && x === x && x !== math.huge && x !== -math.huge (no Number.isFinite)
userStories.notes: Implement each matcher one at a time. Per matcher: impl + spec + types + exports → typecheck → lint → test → commit. Use semantic commits with matcher name as scope, e.g. feat(pass): add pass matcher. Then start next matcher.

userStories.title: Port toBeBetween, toBeWithin, toBeInRange
userStories.description: As a developer, I want range-checking matchers for numbers.
acceptanceCriteria: Create impl + spec for each: to-be-between, to-be-within, to-be-in-range
toBeBetween(startDate, endDate) also supports DateTime via UnixTimestampMillis
Add to CustomMatchers in types.d.ts with correct param types
userStories.notes: Implement each matcher one at a time. Per matcher: impl + spec + types + exports → typecheck → lint → test → commit. Use semantic commits with matcher name as scope, e.g. feat(pass): add pass matcher. Then start next matcher.

userStories.title: Port toBeEmpty and toBeEmptyObject
userStories.description: As a developer, I want matchers to check for empty values and empty objects.
acceptanceCriteria: Create impl + spec for each: to-be-empty, to-be-empty-object
toBeEmptyObject: check table has no keys
userStories.notes: Implement each matcher one at a time. Per matcher: impl + spec + types + exports → typecheck → lint → test → commit. Use semantic commits with matcher name as scope, e.g. feat(pass): add pass matcher. Then start next matcher.

userStories.title: Port toBeFrozen and toBeOneOf
userStories.description: As a developer, I want toBeFrozen (uses table.isfrozen) and toBeOneOf matchers.
acceptanceCriteria: Create impl + spec for each: to-be-frozen, to-be-one-of
toBeFrozen: use table.isfrozen(x as object) instead of Object.isFrozen
toBeOneOf(array): check actual is in the given array
userStories.notes: Implement each matcher one at a time. Per matcher: impl + spec + types + exports → typecheck → lint → test → commit. Use semantic commits with matcher name as scope, e.g. feat(pass): add pass matcher. Then start next matcher.

userStories.title: Port toBeHexadecimal and toBeArrayOfSize
userStories.description: As a developer, I want toBeHexadecimal and toBeArrayOfSize matchers.
acceptanceCriteria: Create impl + spec for each: to-be-hexadecimal, to-be-array-of-size
toBeHexadecimal: use string.match with Luau pattern (no RegExp)
userStories.notes: Implement each matcher one at a time. Per matcher: impl + spec + types + exports → typecheck → lint → test → commit. Use semantic commits with matcher name as scope, e.g. feat(pass): add pass matcher. Then start next matcher.

userStories.title: Port toStartWith, toEndWith, toInclude
userStories.description: As a developer, I want string/array inclusion matchers.
acceptanceCriteria: Create impl + spec for each: to-start-with, to-end-with, to-include
toInclude: handle both string substring and array member checks
userStories.notes: Implement each matcher one at a time. Per matcher: impl + spec + types + exports → typecheck → lint → test → commit. Use semantic commits with matcher name as scope, e.g. feat(pass): add pass matcher. Then start next matcher.

userStories.title: Port toIncludeMultiple and toIncludeRepeated
userStories.description: As a developer, I want matchers for checking multiple substrings and repeated substrings.
acceptanceCriteria: Create impl + spec for each: to-include-multiple, to-include-repeated
toIncludeRepeated(substring, times): substring appears exactly N times
userStories.notes: Implement each matcher one at a time. Per matcher: impl + spec + types + exports → typecheck → lint → test → commit. Use semantic commits with matcher name as scope, e.g. feat(pass): add pass matcher. Then start next matcher.

userStories.title: Port toEqualCaseInsensitive and toEqualIgnoringWhitespace
userStories.description: As a developer, I want string comparison matchers that ignore case or whitespace.
acceptanceCriteria: Create impl + spec for each: to-equal-case-insensitive, to-equal-ignoring-whitespace
toEqualIgnoringWhitespace: use string.match with %s Luau pattern (no RegExp)
userStories.notes: Implement each matcher one at a time. Per matcher: impl + spec + types + exports → typecheck → lint → test → commit. Use semantic commits with matcher name as scope, e.g. feat(pass): add pass matcher. Then start next matcher.

userStories.title: Port toSatisfy, toSatisfyAll, toSatisfyAny
userStories.description: As a developer, I want predicate-based matchers.
acceptanceCriteria: Create impl + spec for each: to-satisfy, to-satisfy-all, to-satisfy-any
toSatisfyAny(predicate): at least one array element passes
userStories.notes: Implement each matcher one at a time. Per matcher: impl + spec + types + exports → typecheck → lint → test → commit. Use semantic commits with matcher name as scope, e.g. feat(pass): add pass matcher. Then start next matcher.

userStories.title: Port toChange, toChangeBy, toChangeTo
userStories.description: As a developer, I want matchers that check if a function changes a value.
acceptanceCriteria: Create impl + spec for each: to-change, to-change-by, to-change-to
toChange(mutator): value returned by subject changes after calling mutator
toChangeBy(mutator, delta): value changes by exactly delta
toChangeTo(mutator, target): value changes to exactly target
userStories.notes: Implement each matcher one at a time. Per matcher: impl + spec + types + exports → typecheck → lint → test → commit. Use semantic commits with matcher name as scope, e.g. feat(pass): add pass matcher. Then start next matcher.

userStories.description: As a developer, I want matchers for checking object keys.
acceptanceCriteria: Create impl + spec for each: to-contain-key, to-contain-keys, to-contain-all-keys, to-contain-any-keys
userStories.notes: Implement each matcher one at a time. Per matcher: impl + spec + types + exports → typecheck → lint → test → commit. Use semantic commits with matcher name as scope, e.g. feat(pass): add pass matcher. Then start next matcher.

Use contains() from src/utils for deep equality checks
userStories.notes: Implement each matcher one at a time. Per matcher: impl + spec + types + exports → typecheck → lint → test → commit. Use semantic commits with matcher name as scope, e.g. feat(pass): add pass matcher. Then start next matcher.

userStories.title: Port toHaveBeenCalledOnce and toHaveBeenCalledExactlyOnceWith
userStories.description: As a developer, I want mock call count matchers.
acceptanceCriteria: Create impl + spec for each: to-have-been-called-once, to-have-been-called-exactly-once-with
Use jest.isMockFunction() from src/utils to validate mock
jest.fn() returns [mock, fn] — tests must destructure both
userStories.notes: Implement each matcher one at a time. Per matcher: impl + spec + types + exports → typecheck → lint → test → commit. Use semantic commits with matcher name as scope, e.g. feat(pass): add pass matcher. Then start next matcher.

jest.fn() returns [mock, fn] — tests must destructure both
